factoid: Bolkónski thought that the Orthodox Russian army was dear.
Bolkónski recalled Bilíbin's words.
Bolkónski wished to find out where the commander in chief was.
Bolkónski rode up to a convoy.
A strange one-horse vehicle appeared opposite Bolkónski.
The vehicle was rigged up by soldiers using available materials.
The vehicle looked like something between a cart, a cabriolet, and a calèche.
A soldier was driving the one-horse vehicle.
A woman in shawls sat behind the apron under the leather hood of the vehicle.
Prince Andrew rode up.
Prince Andrew was asking a question to the soldier.
Prince Andrew's attention was diverted by the desperate shrieks of the woman in the vehicle.
The woman screamed piercingly.
The woman saw Prince Andrew.
The woman leaned out from behind the apron.
The woman waved her thin arms from under the woolen shawl.

The woman cried: "Mr. Aide-de-camp! Mr. Aide-de-camp!... For heaven’s sake... Protect me! What will become of us? I am the wife of the doctor of the Seventh Chasseurs.... They won’t let us pass, we are left behind and have lost our people..."
The angry officer shouted to the soldier: "I’ll flatten you into a pancake!"
The angry officer shouted to the soldier: "Turn back with your slut!"
The doctor’s wife screamed: "Mr. Aide-de-camp! Help me!... What does it all mean?"
Prince Andrew said: "Kindly let this cart pass. Don’t you see it’s a woman?" when he rode up to the officer.
The officer glanced at Prince Andrew.
The officer turned again to the soldier.
The officer shouted: "I’ll teach you to push on!... Back!"
Prince Andrew repeated: "Let them pass, I tell you!" while compressing his lips.
The officer cried: "And who are you?"
The officer turned on Prince Andrew with tipsy rage.
The officer said: "who are you? Are you in command here? Eh? I am commander here, not you! Go back or I’ll flatten you into a pancake," and repeated it.
The expression pleased the officer.
A voice from behind said: "That was a nice snub for the little aide-de-camp."
Prince Andrew saw that the officer was in a state of senseless, tipsy rage.
Prince Andrew saw that championing the doctor’s wife might expose Prince Andrew to ridicule.
Prince Andrew's instinct urged him on.
Before the officer finished his sentence, Prince Andrew rode up to the officer.
Prince Andrew's face was distorted with fury.
Prince Andrew raised his riding whip.
Prince Andrew said: "Kind...ly let—them—pass!"
The officer flourished his arm.
The officer hastily rode away.
The officer muttered: "It’s all the fault of these fellows on the staff that there’s this disorder."
The officer said: "Do as you like."
Prince Andrew rode hastily away from the doctor’s wife.
The doctor’s wife called Prince Andrew her deliverer.
Prince Andrew recalled with a sense of disgust the details of the humiliating scene.
Prince Andrew galloped to the village.
In the village, Prince Andrew was told who the commander in chief was.
Prince Andrew reached the village.
Prince Andrew dismounted.
Prince Andrew went to the nearest house.
Prince Andrew intended to rest for a moment.
Prince Andrew intended to eat something.
Prince Andrew intended to try to sort out his stinging and tormenting thoughts.
Prince Andrew thought: "This is a mob of scoundrels and not an army."
Prince Andrew went up to the window of the first house.
A familiar voice called Prince Andrew by name.
Prince Andrew turned round.
Nesvítski’s face looked out of the little window.
Nesvítski chewed something.
Nesvítski flourished his arm.
Nesvítski called Prince Andrew to enter.
Nesvítski shouted: "Bolkónski! Bolkónski!... Don’t you hear? Eh? Come quick..."
Prince Andrew entered the house.
Prince Andrew saw Nesvítski.
Prince Andrew saw another adjutant.
The adjutant and Nesvítski were having something to eat.
The adjutant and Nesvítski hastily turned round to Prince Andrew.
The adjutant and Nesvítski asked if Prince Andrew had any news.
Prince Andrew read agitation and alarm on their familiar faces.
The agitation and alarm was particularly noticeable on Nesvítski’s usually laughing countenance.
Bolkónski asked: "Where is the commander in chief?"
The adjutant answered: "Here, in that house."
Nesvítski asked: "Well, is it true that it’s peace and capitulation?"
